version_semver_justification: ROOT traditionally uses a different versioning scheme.
vulnerability_report_response_justificat: Only one security-related incident; public reaction < 1d: https://root-forum.cern.ch/t/google-considers-root-cern-unsafe/41676
test_most_justification: 83% of ROOT's classes are tested, but only 31% of its branches
warnings_strict_justification: 0 warning goal for releases and even HEADs of development branches
know_secure_design_justification: Several core developers trained in secure software, also thanks to consulting from CERN IT security
know_common_errors_justification: Several core developers trained in secure software, also thanks to consulting from CERN IT security
crypto_keylength_justification: ROOT does not itself configure keylengths; this is delegated (xrootd etc).
crypto_working_justification: ROOT does not itself configure algorithms; this is delegated (xrootd etc).
crypto_pfs_justification: ROOT does not itself configure key agreement protocols; this is delegated (xrootd etc).
crypto_random_justification: ROOT does not itself generate cryptographic keys and nonces; this is delegated (xrootd etc).
dynamic_analysis_justification:
valgrind is run on a subset of tests as part of the release procedure: https://root.cern/for_developers/release_checklist/
clang's address sanitizer is run on ROOT and its test suite as part of the CI.
dynamic_analysis_unsafe_justification:
valgrind is routinely used.
clang's address sanitizer is run on ROOT and its test suite as part of the CI.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: CI builds and tests have asserts enabled
dynamic_analysis_fixed_justification: We are not aware of existing vulnerabilities.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: ROOT does not itself configure algorithms; this is delegated (xrootd etc).
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Currently Jenkins-based and due to security considerations behind login
discussion_justification:
GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
Forum https://root-forum.cern.ch/

name: JanusGraph
description: JanusGraph is a highly scalable graph database optimized for storing and querying large graphs with billions of vertices and edges distributed across a multi-machine cluster. JanusGraph is a transactional database that can support thousands of concurrent users, complex traversals, and analytic graph queries.
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/LICENSE.txt>.
floss_license_justification: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/LICENSE.txt The code is covered by the Apache-2.0 license which is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI). The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Source documentation: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/tree/master/docs
Target documentation website: https://docs.janusgraph.org
documentation_interface_justification:
Source documentation: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/tree/master/docs
Target documentation website: https://docs.janusgraph.org
Javadoc: https://javadoc.io/doc/org.janusgraph/janusgraph-core/latest/index.html
Documentation building process: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/BUILDING.md#building-documentation
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: Interim versions are available as Draft releases in GitHub during voting process which takes at least 72 hours. See the release process here: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/RELEASING.md
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
release_notes_justification:
Release notes are provided for MINOR (Feature) releases: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/releases
Changelog & Upgrade instructions (if needed) between releases are provided here:https://docs.janusgraph.org/changelog
release_notes_vulns_justification:
Each release have a link to closed milestone issues.
Vulnerability issues are marked with `kind/security` label. 
You can see what vulnerabilities were fixed for any of the release: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/issues?q=security+label%3Akind%2Fsecurity+is%3Aclosed
report_process_justification:
For confirmed bugs: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/issues
For unconfirmed bugs: https://lists.lfaidata.foundation/g/janusgraph-users/topics
test_most_justification: 73% is covered as for July 17 2021 which is most of the code.
test_policy_justification:
2 codecov actions are integrated for each PR which check the following:
- Patch is covered at least "current coverage - 5%"
- Project overall covered after applying this PR is at least "current coverage - 5%"
tests_are_added_justification: For new features and or bugfixes we require test covarage: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/.github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE.md
warnings_justification:
Linter is used and the PR will not be passed without following the linter rules. CI for linter: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/.github/workflows/lint-proto.yml
Codacy is used for each provided PR.
warnings_fixed_justification: Warning from individual PRs are addressed when they appear unless project maintainers deem that this warning is false positive in which situation the warning is either disabled or an explanation is written in a PR for a specific warning.
general_comments:
JanusGraph is a project under The Linux Foundation. 
JanusGraph is a part of LF AI & Data umbrella: https://landscape.lfai.foundation/card-mode?project=incubating&selected=janus-graph
discussion_justification:
GitHub Discussions, Issues and Pull requests are enabled.
The community channels described here: https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph#community
hardening_justification: The handshake mechanism is used to detect all live nodes.
crypto_tls12_justification: The project supports TLS 1.2. See SSL configuration options: https://docs.janusgraph.org/master/configs/configuration-reference
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: TLS certificate verification. See SSL configuration options: https://docs.janusgraph.org/master/configs/configuration-reference
hardened_site_justification: // X-Content-Type-Options was not set to "nosniff".
implementation_languages: Java, Shell, Groovy, Batchfile, Dockerfile, Python, Makefile
dco_justification: We use both a CLA and DCO; this is described in https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md
access_continuity_justification:
LF AI & Data Foundation has access to all the necessary services to run the project (i.e. passwords and admin rights to all the services used by JanusGraph). This is the requirement to be included in the foundation.
https://landscape.lfai.foundation/card-mode?project=incubating&selected=janus-graph
bus_factor_justification:
Used the next tool: https://github.com/elek/bus-factor (v1.0.0).
The results are:
Pony number: 3
  dalaro@hopcount.org 1888
  me@matthiasb.com 1254
  okrammarko@gmail.com 782
Dev power 3.39
AVL bus factor: 2
  dalaro@hopcount.org
  okrammarko@gmail.com
documentation_current_justification:
The documentation is provided for each MINOR release.
https://docs.janusgraph.org
Moreover, up to 0.4.0 release the documentation was generated for each release including PATCH releases. The old documentation is available here:
https://old-docs.janusgraph.org
sites_password_security_justification: Project website doesn't store any passwords.
maintenance_or_update_justification:
The project maintain the most popular versions of the software (latest 2 versions).
The upgrade guide between versions is available here: https://docs.janusgraph.org/changelog
build_standard_variables_justification: The project is build used Maven and respects any provided configurations for a build.
build_preserve_debug_justification: The project is build used Maven and respects any provided configurations for a build.
build_non_recursive_justification: The project is build used Maven and respects any provided configurations for a build.
build_repeatable_justification: The project is build used Maven and respects any provided configurations for a build.
external_dependencies_justification:
All the used dependencies are provided in release files.
https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/releases
updateable_reused_components_justificati: The user can easily exclude any vulnerable libraries and include upgrade libraries via any build automation tool (i.e. Maven, Gradle, etc.).
interfaces_current_justification: The project tries to remove usage of any deprecated or obsolete functions where possible.
automated_integration_testing_justificat: GitHub Actions is used to check in all branches and all PRs
regression_tests_added50_justification: Maintainers try to cover all fixed bugs with tests
input_validation_justification: The input is checked to be valid by the underlying drivers.
signed_releases_justification:
https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/releases
All the release artifacts are signed. The KEYS is attached to all the releases to retrieve the necessary keys.
contributors_unassociated_justification:
Most (or all) the contributors in the project are unassociated.
https://github.com/orgs/JanusGraph/people
https://github.com/JanusGraph/janusgraph/graphs/contributors
copyright_per_file_justification: All source files have copyright and license headers
license_per_file_justification: All source files have copyright and license headers
two_person_review_justification: 2 project committer approvals are required to merge a PR or 1 project committer approval following by 1 week of no other reviews is required to merge a PR.

name: krator
description: Kubernetes Rust State Machine Operator
contribution_justification: Non-trivial contribution file in repository: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md>.
contribution_requirements_justification: Developer guide description of testing procedures: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/docs/community/developers.md#testing>
license_location_justification: Non-trivial license location file in repository: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/LICENSE>.
floss_license_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
floss_license_osi_justification: The Apache-2.0 license is approved by the Open Source Initiative (OSI).
documentation_basics_justification:
Project documentation: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/tree/main/docs>.
API documentation: <https://docs.rs/krator/0.3.0/krator/>.
Example of library usage: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/tree/main/krator/examples>.
repo_public_justification: Repository on GitHub, which provides public git repositories with URLs.
repo_track_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git can track the changes, who made them, and when they were made.
repo_interim_justification: All incremental pull requests are reviewed using this repository.
repo_distributed_justification: Repository on GitHub, which uses git. git is distributed.
version_unique_justification: We follow semantic versioning for each release.
version_tags_justification: Each release is tagged with its version number.
release_notes_justification: Release notes are documented using GitHub: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/releases>.
release_notes_vulns_justification: This project has not had any reported CVEs, but would note any fixes in release notes should that happen.
report_tracker_justification: We use GitHub issues to track individual issues: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/issues>.
report_process_justification: We use GitHub issues to track any reported bugs: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/issues>.
report_responses_justification: This project will and has acknowledged any submitted bug issues.
enhancement_responses_justification: This project has a documented history of responding to enhancement requests from the community.
report_archive_justification: We use GitHub issues to archive closed issues: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/issues?q=is%3Aissue+is%3Aclosed>.
build_justification: This project uses Rust's package manager Cargo and the Rust compiler exclusively.
build_common_tools_justification: Cargo is the standard build tool in the Rust ecosystem.
test_justification: This project uses Rust's built in testing functionality. Tests are run on every pull request.
test_invocation_justification: Tests are run in the standard way using the Rust test toolchain, and documented: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/docs/community/developers.md#testing>.
test_most_justification: The test suite includes unit, documentation, and "ui" tests which validate compiler behavior. Compatibility test with Kubernetes API schema are done at compile time. Integration tests w/ Kubernetes do not currently exist, because this is a library, but could be developed in the future.
test_policy_justification: Contributors are encouraged to add testing for major new functionality, and test cases are added as any edge cases are discovered.
tests_are_added_justification: In Krator's latest release a complex derive macro was introduced which included an extensive test suite: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/krator-derive/tests/admission.rs>.
tests_documented_added_justification: This policy will be enforced based on the judgement of the maintainers.
warnings_justification: This project uses Rust's clippy tool to lint all pull requests, and has a policy of not permitting any "warnings".
warnings_fixed_justification: This project has a policy of eliminating any warnings produced by its linting tool, clippy, including new warnings that occur when clippy is updated (with each release of Rust).
warnings_strict_justification: The maintainers require that warnings be fixed before pull requests are merged.
know_secure_design_justification: Kevin Flansburg, can be contacted via channels listed on GitHub profile
crypto_published_justification: Cryptographic algorithms used by this software are those required to connect to Kubernetes API Server via TLS and host a webhook using mTLS using user-provider key pair.
crypto_call_justification: This project uses either OpenSSL (default) or RusTLS (a Rust-native alternative), depending on compilation options. <https://github.com/ctz/rustls>.
crypto_keylength_justification: OpenSSL can be configured to restrict which cipher suites are accepted.
crypto_working_justification: This software uses modern TLS protocols which should not make use of these algorithms. If there is an exception, OpenSSL can be configured to restrict which cipher suites are accepted.
crypto_pfs_justification: OpenSSL (and TLS protocol) support this with ECDH, the use of which depends on the user's system configuration.
static_analysis_common_vulnerabilities_j: Clippy would be the tool to detect issues that _can_ be detected with static analysis.
static_analysis_often_justification:
Source code is inspected on every pull request. 
Additionally, plans are in place to run some tests nightly (including detecting CVEs reported for dependencies): <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/issues/42>.
dynamic_analysis_justification: This software does not directly parse external input, it use libraries for this. These libraries should perform this kind of validation.
dynamic_analysis_enable_assertions_justi: If dynamic analysis were used, this software can support debug-time assertions, and already makes use of this functionality in some places). There are additional checks inserted by the compiler itself when compiled for debugging.
test_continuous_integration_justificatio: Every pull request and push to the default branch, main, is tested using GitHub actions. This involves running all builds and tests using a matrix of target architectures and feature flags: <https://github.com/krator-rs/krator/blob/main/.github/workflows/build.yml>.
discussion_justification: GitHub supports discussions on issues and pull requests.
hardened_site_justification: Found all required security hardening headers.

build_justification: We use Dockerfile to build the container images. The build automatically run with Gitlab CI

build_floss_tools_justification: We only use FLOSS tools and dependencies, we have license scanning on our CI to prevent license incompatibility
test_justification: We use Gitlab CI with PHP Unit. Please see: https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/djp-iam/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml
test_policy_justification: Yes, we use automated scanning on our CI. Please see: https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/djp-iam/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml
tests_are_added_justification: Yes, we use automated scanning on our CI. Please see: https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/djp-iam/-/blob/master/.gitlab-ci.yml

warnings_fixed_justification: We do use warning flags from the Gitlab CI output. If the warnings is fixed, it shows on the next CI test.

crypto_published_justification: We use Argon2id for password hashing, and we use RSA Public Private Key to secure JWT token.

delivery_unsigned_justification: Yes, by default by caddy web server

static_analysis_often_justification: Every commit will trigger Gitlab CI ,deepsource and codacy to run the scanner.
dynamic_analysis_justification: We use Gitlab SAST and DAST for Static Analysis and Dynamic Analysis. Furthermore, we also implement code scanner by deepsource and codacy to improve the safe coding.
crypto_weaknesses_justification: We use RSA-4096 for cryptographic hash algorithm on the public and private key for token generator, and we use Argon2id for hash mechanism
discussion_justification: Every discussion is happened on the Gitlab Issue page, please see: https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/issues
no_leaked_credentials_justification: We use Gitlab Secret Scanning on CI to detect this.
hardening_justification: The software generate token for authentication, so the token is encrypted as part of the hardening mechanism. https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/security/dashboard

crypto_tls12_justification: Yes, please see the web server config at https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/caddy/Caddyfile or https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/nginx/nginx.conf
crypto_certificate_verification_justific: Yes, please see the web server config at https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/caddy/Caddyfile or https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/nginx/nginx.conf
crypto_verification_private_justificatio: Yes, please see the web server config at https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/caddy/Caddyfile or https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/blob/master/docker/nginx/nginx.conf

internationalization_justification: We do use English as main language
vulnerability_report_credit_justificatio: Every vulnerability report will be reported from https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/releases, it tracks who solved and we use confidential feature of Gitlab Issue for vulnerability.
vulnerability_response_process_justifica: We use Gitlab vulnerability report for the documentation. https://gitlab.com/dadangnh/iam/-/security/vulnerability_report

name: bucket
description:
Bucket is a cloud application that supports design researchers and practitioners to collect and explore behavioural data with active participation from all stakeholders.

Its concept of Things facilitates the prototyping of live data prototypes.

Its concepts of Apps facilitate the prototyping of web and mobile data explorers, customised for the appropriate insights and reflections tasks. 

You acquire data through an App from data donation, crowdsourcing or landing pages; you collect data by prototyping an Arduino, Rasberry Pi or custom-based device that you land to participants; or you directly upload data from files. Then, you explore the harvested time series with a generic tool such as Grafana. You can export the data to use it in your prefered data tool at all times. Finally, you customise an App to explore and annotate with participants.

Data is strongly typed to facilitate transfer and automate processing. But you create you can create your types (e.g. data structures) adapted to your need.

Data is locked by default in its Things, only accessible by its owner. You grant and revoke access to your data at your convenience.

Installation information is at https://github.com/datacentricdesign/bucket/blob/master/doc/INSTALL.md and other materials are at https://github.com/datacentricdesign/bucket/blob/master/doc. The doc is formatted and served at https://dwd.tudelft.nl/bucket/.
documentation_interface_justification: Both HTTP (REST) and MQTT APIs are described at https://github.com/datacentricdesign/bucket/blob/master/doc/references/api.md.
